item.title: Special-Needs Children
item.dc:creator: dave
item.content:encoded:
Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyer

Special Needs Children and Divorce in New Jersey

Raising a child with special needs can be tough on a marriage. As a result, the divorce rate of parents of special needs children is higher than the national divorce rate of 50% of all couples. A divorce between a couple with a special needs child involves several issues that may not come into play in a typical divorce. New Jersey Special Needs lawyer, Richard C. Klein, is well-versed in the many issues that arise in these cases and has represented many parents of children with special needs, such as those with autism spectrum disorders.

New Jersey Special Needs Lawyers Fight for the Proper Child Support Award

When a couple with a special needs child divorces and child support issues are determined, consideration of the financial, medical and therapy needs of this child is even more crucial than those of their other children. Since a special needs child, such as a child with autism, often has more expenses than a child without special needs, New Jersey child support guidelines do not adequately address those needs. Therefore, your New Jersey Special Needs attorney must be prepared to present a case that demonstrates why the court should deviate from the guidelines. New Jersey child support guidelines do not take into account the many extraordinary expenses associated with providing care and quality of life for a special needs child, including therapy (speech, occupational and physical), special education, home health care, medications, specialized cars and a wide-range of assistive devices. A support award that routinely applies the child support guidelines to a special needs situation would not sufficiently cover the actual costs of raising a special needs child. This is when you need a New Jersey Special Needs lawyer who will fight against strict adherence to the Guidelines. As a New Jersey Special Needs attorney regularly handling divorce cases involving developmentally disabled and autistic children, family law attorney, Richard C. Klein, Esq. has successfully argued in many New Jersey courtrooms that the special circumstances of children with special needs requires that the Court deviate from guidelines and increase the child support award. Based in Cherry Hill, Camden County, New Jersey, Richard Klein is compassionate and caring, yet aggressive when it comes to getting you the child support you need to properly care for your special needs child. And once you receive a just child support award, he can design the necessary Special Needs Trusts to protect your child's right to government benefits. Read more about Special Needs Trusts here.

New Jersey Special Need Lawyers Understand the Other Considerations: Education, Guardianship & Emancipation

Divorcing parents of a special needs child need to decide who is responsible to make educational decisions for the child. Also, if the child will require a lifetime guardian, the parents must consider which parent, if not both, will become guardian once the child turns 18 years of age and is not able to be emancipated. Generally, "emancipation" usually occurs once a child reaches the age of majority, graduates from high school, or graduates from college; however, this is not simply a date that passes, but rather, an event in the eyes of the law. The key concern is that emancipation occurs when a child moves beyond the "sphere of influence" of a parent and achieves an independent status on his or her own. Most special needs children may never move beyond their parents' "sphere of influence." If the special needs child is incapable of maintaining himself due to his illness or disorder then the Court will not declare the child emancipated. A parent may be required to support a special needs child even though he's reached the age of majority. In many cases, a child with special needs may never be declared emancipated and child support could continue indefinitely.

Considering Divorce: Consult with the Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyer at the Law Firm of Richard C. Klein, Esq.

Divorce is an emotionally difficult time for parents and having a child with special needs adds to the uncertainty and worry. If you are a divorcing parent of an autistic or developmentally disabled child, you will need to retain an attorney well-versed in public benefits planning and establishing Special Needs Trusts who can help you take full advantage of the governmental benefits owed to your child. The New Jersey Special Needs Trust attorneys of the Law Firm of Richard C. Klein, Esq. have the experience, dedication and compassion to help you work through your divorce and protect the best interests of your special needs child. Our New Jersey Special Needs lawyers practice throughout the State and are well-respected in Burlington County, Camden County, Gloucester County, Hunterdon County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Salem County and Somerset County divorce courts. Call New Jersey Special Needs attorney, Richard C. Klein, Esq., today at 856-528-0822 or contact him online to discuss your divorce and how to protect the rights of your special needs child. item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyer: Impact of Divorce on Credit
item.dc:creator: lynn
item.content:encoded:
It is common knowledge that divorce can be expensive. According to a recent survey by Experian, the average American loses about $20,000 in cash and other assets as a result of divorce. Many of these expenses stem from finding a new place to live and potentially having to make payments on two dwellings at once. Other expenses include temporary alimony and child support orders, legal fees, and the need to hire outside professionals to complete the divorce process. Over time, these expenses can add up, leaving many individuals feeling broke by the time their divorce is finalized. For many newly-divorced individuals, the financial consequences of divorce are two-fold. In addition to the extra money spent during divorce, many also experience a drop in their credit score. This occurs for a few reasons. During the divorce process, stress and tight finances can force individuals to make financially risky decisions. Another reason is that married couples are jointly liable for any debt incurred during their marriages. When a couple divorces, these debts are divided alongside their assets.

Protecting Your Credit During Divorce

While your divorce is pending, many small expenses will come up. You might need to hire a babysitter for your children while you attend a meeting with your lawyer. You might need to miss a few days at work to go to court. On top of this, you may be struggling to adjust to living with only one salary if you were used to having two to help  provide for your daily living expenses. This can put a further strain on you and force you to live on credit. If you take this route, pay off all your credit card bills in full and on time. If you cannot pay your bills in full, pay as much as you can to avoid compounding interest in following months. Your credit score is calculated by examining your payment history, the length of your credit history, the type of credit used, the amount of money you currently owe, and any new credit line you obtain. By closing your joint credit accounts and opening new accounts, you can potentially damage your credit score. It is highly recommended that you seek the advice of an experienced New Jersey divorce lawyer before making any big changes to your finances.

Debt Liability

All debts incurred during a marriage may be considered marital debt, which means that both parties are liable for the debt. Exceptions include debts listed in a prenuptial agreement, stating that the debt belongs only to the partner who incurred it. Without these provisions, you can potentially find yourself facing steep debt for your partner’s college education, shopping or gambling habits, medical bills, or other expenses after your divorce. Talk to your lawyer about seeking innocent spouse relief through the IRS, which can release you from the liability. If you have shared debt with your former partner, work with them to pay down the debt together. One way to do this is to share the login information for the online account so you can both monitor it and make payments as necessary.

Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyer Richard C. Klein Helps Clients Avoid Credit Damage During Divorce

If you are considering filing for divorce, take steps early to protect your financial future. Contact an experienced Cherry Hill divorce lawyer who can help you work through all aspects of your divorce, including protecting your credit. Complete our online form or call 856-988-5470 to set up your initial consultation with Richard C. Klein, P.A. Our office is located in Marlton, New Jersey, where we work with clients throughout South Jersey.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Divorce Impact on Older Women’s Health
item.dc:creator: lynn
item.content:encoded:
A recent study from the University of Arizona found that post-menopausal women who divorce or separate from their spouses tend to lose weight and experience other positive health effects when their marriages end. The study examined lifestyle factors like exercise, alcohol consumption, smoking, and weight gain in women age 50 to 79 over a period of three years. Women in cohabitating relationships were considered married for the purposes of the study. The women who divorced during the study had the most improved diets and had more active lifestyles than the other categories at the end of the study. Compared to the other categories, the divorced women also tended to lose weight. The women fell into four categories:
  • Those who began the three year period unmarried and remained unmarried at the end
  • Those who were married at the beginning and end of the study
  • Those who were single when the study began and married by its conclusion
  • Those who were married when it began and divorced or separated at its end

Conscious Choices About Health Come With Divorce

The researchers first hypothesized that the divorced women’s weight loss could be due to depression following their divorces. Contrary this this theory, they found that the divorced women actively attempted to create healthier lifestyles and that the weight loss stemmed from this. In contrast, the women who remained married through the course of the study and those who married at some point during it gained weight in the three year period. On average, they gained two pounds. Study authors indicate the findings could be attributed to divorced women’s newfound focus on themselves, rather than on their identities as wives. Women cooking for themselves and eating alone may consume smaller portions and thus, fewer calories than they did when they ate with their partners.

Marriage, Divorce, and Health Trends

The study found that women whose marital status did not change during the study saw a decrease in diastolic blood pressure, particularly the women who remained unmarried. Between the married and divorced women, alcohol consumption was approximately the same. The women who began and ended the study single tended to drink less alcohol than other groups. One area where the divorcees health choices were worse than the other groups’ was smoking. The study found that the women who began the study married and were divorced by its conclusion were more likely than other groups to begin smoking. The researchers noted, though, that these women tended to be former smokers who had quit previously and picked up the habit again following their divorces, rather than first-time smokers.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyer: Things to Know About Divorce and Special Needs Children
item.dc:creator: lynn
item.content:encoded:
Divorce is difficult for both parents and children, but when a special needs child is involved, finding the best solution can be tricky. Families often rely on pubic programs for an array of medical and financial needs to properly care for their disabled child. Without careful planning, divorce and the resulting court-sanctioned settlements may derail many such programs. This can cause unforeseen difficulties for both parents and the child. Government benefits such as Social Security and Medicaid help families defray the increasing costs of caring for children with special needs. However, these benefits are subject to incomes derived by parents. Although a couple with a disabled child may qualify for benefits while together, when divorced, child support and alimony payments may cause complications. Divorcing parents need to consider such matters during the settlement process lest they find themselves unable to adequately care for their disabled child’s current and future needs.

Factors That Impact Eligibility for Special Needs Social Services

In considering eligible income for purposes of providing needed supplemental coverage, the value of a home, the direct income earned by parents, and certain investments may be used. In addition, the age of the child, the exact nature of the disability, and life insurance proceeds may impact the ability of a special needs child to receive public assistance. A parent will want to avoid anything that may cut the child off from public benefits because obtaining these later may be more difficult. Some of the ways to prevent disruption of benefits is to set up a special needs trust for the child. A trust will ensure that the benefits remain intact while the support is paid to a trustee rather than directly to the child. Take insurance for example. When parents divorce, a common practice is to remove the former spouse as a primary beneficiary and name the child. This can cause the child to have the policy counted as income. A trust can prevent this outcome. Another factor to consider is the situation of social services rendered to one of the parents. Some parents may be receiving SSI themselves. If a child is under the age of 22 at the time the parent begins to receive Social Security payments, the child may be eligible to draw a payment which is separate and does not impact the parent’s income.

Divorce is difficult and the laws related to providing for special needs children can make it more so. The Cherry Hill divorce lawyers at the law offices of Richard C. item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Special Needs Children and Divorce Study
item.dc:creator: mike
item.content:encoded:
Divorce is often seen as a problem between two married people, but studies indicate that special needs children may contribute to the divorce rate. Although children should never be blamed for a divorce, children with special needs do place an added strain on marriage. Some partners may find that the issues arising from dealing with their children are more than they can bear, while in other cases, the difficulties associated with raising such children may highlight differences in values between parents. Either situation can result in higher divorce rates. Consider some examples. Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a disorder which causes children to lack the ability to be attentive. They are hyperactive and impulsive. This can cause them to ignore parents, run into danger, be fidgety, have difficulty playing quietly, lack focus, be impatient, and not follow social rules. Such a child can be a challenge to parents and unless both are willing to work together on a strategy to help their child, divisions can occur. Not surprising then, a study by Wymbs and Pelham found that divorce rates among parents with an ADHD child were much higher than average. Likewise, a study by Hartley et al. found that parents with autistic children were much more likely to divorce. Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) causes a child to have difficulty with social skills, communication, and behavior. Autism can be mild or severe but in every instance, parents face unique challenges which place a strain on relationships if both are not unified in their approach to child-rearing. Both studies found that if parents remained together after the child reached the age of 8, their chances of divorce became the same as the general population.

Special Needs Children and Divorce: An Interesting Twist

Urbano and Hodapp considered the divorce rates among parents with a Down’s Syndrome child. They found that rates among these parents were much lower than average but if a divorce did occur, it was most likely prior to the child reaching the age of two. Down’s Syndrome is a genetic condition caused by an extra chromosome. This extra genetic material results in eyes slanted upwards, small stature, and low muscle tone. Children with Down’s Syndrome have cognitive difficulties which range from mild to severe and often may be stubborn. In fact, such special needs children possess many of the same behavior traits as those with ADHD and ASD so the findings of this study are perplexing by comparison. Regardless of the reasons, ample research indicates that although children may never be to blame for a divorce, they do factor into the equation. Parents need to keep this in mind and remember that their children are a gift, regardless of their special needs and the challenges these pose.

In such divorces, both parents generally remain committed to ensuring that the best interests of their children are met. We are committed to helping parents through such a difficult time. item.title: Cherry Hill Child Custody Lawyers: Tri-Custody Case
item.dc:creator: lynn
item.content:encoded:
A recent custody battle resulted in a rather unique outcome for a boy and his parents, with a New York judge awarding custody to not two, but three people. A married couple struggling to conceive a child with multiple miscarriages began a polyamorous relationship with their female neighbor, who later gave birth to a boy. According to court documents, the couple and neighbor considered themselves a large family and had planned to raise the child as one unit, but this plan fell apart when the wife and neighbor left, taking the child with them, and moved in together as a new couple. The husband and wife filed for divorce, creating a custody battle with a tough decision for the judge. The boy, now 10  years old, spends most of his time with his two mothers, and his father has regular visitation rights. The husband of the original couple was not in favor of a three-way custody, while the boy's biological mother was, and the wife wanted to have legal parenting rights despite not being the biological mother of the child. According to the judge, this decision was crucial to the child's well-being, and would result in a more stable home life for the boy.

The Future of Polyamory and Multiple Custody

This type of custody was previously relatively unheard of until this point, but the increasing prevalence of polyamory means that cases like this may become a frequent courtroom concern in the future. With the traditional family dynamic in the United States and other parts of the world starting to break apart into more varied structures, adapting our perception of child custody to the modern family is increasingly important. The tri-custody ruling was framed in the courtroom as a new but perfectly valid application of equal marriage rights, with previous cases setting precedent for non-biological parents to share custody of children. This case too will likely set future precedent for similar cases, especially as they apply to those in polyamorous or queer relationships. Detractors of this type of social progress argue that allowing those in non-traditional relationships to retain custody in a similar case will lead to the breaking down of societal norms. Proponents argue much the same thing, from the standpoint that traditional societal norms may not be worth defending.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers Discuss Child Custody and Emotionally Impacted Parents
item.dc:creator: mike
item.content:encoded:
Child custody is determined by “the best interest of the child.” That is a highly subjective standard although we do have certain criteria set forth in our statute, one of the issues that we often see, and perhaps missed as a factor is the parent who, although loving to the child(ren) suffers from an emotional or psychological illness that simply prevents them from exercising the kind of judgment that serves the child well. Issues such as Bi-polar disorder, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) or Anger Management issues are all conditions that impact the decision of who should be the primary custodial parent. Therefore, many attorneys fail to suggest to their clients that they request that the Court order a psychiatric or psychological evaluation of the other parent. This, if granted can be a critical factor in determining which parent should have primary custody.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Loneliness After Divorce
item.dc:creator: lynn
item.content:encoded:
After a person divorces, loneliness often sets in. This is both normal and inevitable. Being lonely following a divorce is normal because humans are social creatures. It is easy to become accustomed to having another person in our life. We become conditioned to the experience, but being alone does not mean we must be lonely.

Why People are Often Lonely After Divorce and What Can be Done

After years together, couples become comfortable with each another. After a divorce, the sudden change is uncomfortable. This is due to a psychological function called conditioning. To combat the loneliness that comes with divorce, begin to think about all the things that you could not do before. Perhaps she hated when you had friends over. Maybe he did not like going to the same places as you. Such restrictions no longer apply. The natural constraints of marriage may have hindered your career or passions. You can spend more time at the office advancing your career in ways you could not before. You can hold house parties, starting small at first with just a few friends over. You can more readily travel because you no longer have two schedules to juggle. If someone asks you to join them for an event, you can accept without having to check with anyone else. Something else which will help is going to the gym. This is not necessarily for social reasons, but rather for the physiological benefits. After a good workout, circulation is better and natural chemicals flood the brain and body. This will help clear your mind and allow you to feel better alone. Most importantly, do not worry about being alone. Just do not jump into a new relationship until you are comfortable alone because that could cause you to make a choice you may later regret. Take some time to enjoy yourself and clear your thoughts. Become your own person again.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers Discuss Special Needs Children and Custody
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Over the past 10 years or so, the child with special needs has taken front and center with regard to school, treatment and awareness. However, one area that is often overlooked by those going through divorce or separation is how the special needs of a child can impact not just custody in general, but, the parenting time schedule as well.
Although the Courts tend to prefer that both parents enjoy similar time with their child(ren), the special needs of that child should make the court take a much closer look at what is in their best interest.  Many special needs children require the consistency and predictability of being in one primary home for the vast majority of the time.  They tend to adjust to their environment better and overall do better emotionally and scholastically.  Unfortunately, many judges do not fully understand that.  Therefore, it is vital for you to work closely with an attorney who has had significant experience with the special needs child and how to educate the Court, often through the use of experts, to why a “typical” visitation schedule may simply not be right for a particular child.  In my practice, I have represented hundreds of clients with special needs children and once a Court truly understand what that means, the parenting time schedule can tilt heavily toward the parent who has the best grasp of their child’s issues.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Baby Boomer Divorce Rates Are Rising
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Divorce rates have increased within the United States over the past few decades, but one demographic has seen a significant increase in divorce rates over the last 20 years – couples over 50. Numerous factors are at play here, from changing social conventions to longer life expectancy. This phenomenon, known as “gray divorce,” has been an increasingly important factor to consider, as couples live longer. Financial planners and marriage counselors advise that, as couples approach old age with the prospect of continuing to live for decades, they have greater expectations than older couples have in the past. Many older couples expect this greater quality of life because they have finished raising their children, are financially stable, and tend to be active longer both socially and physically. Due to all these factors, gray divorce has roughly doubled over the past 25 years. Recent studies have shown that gray divorce is more likely among partners that have been married more than once, or who have not been married for more than a few years. Those who have been married fewer than 10 years are around twice as likely to divorce than those who have been married for more than 20, and five times as likely compared to those married more than 40 years. Seniors in their second marriage are twice as likely to divorce as those still in their first marriage.

Gray Divorce Contributes to Financial Concerns

Housing and stock markets have become increasingly unstable, and financial issues can rear their ugly heads for those heading into retirement. Separating from your partner can make these financial issues even worse, emphasizing the importance of financial planning going into retirement. One study suggested that this is especially true among those involved in their second or third marriage, especially when children are factored into the situation. Multiple sets of kids competing for resources can present a noticeable burden on resources, and divorce can throw a wrench into the gears of those whose retirement plans are tightly calculated. For older couples experiencing marriage issues or heading toward a divorce, adjusting financial plans and forming realistic expectations for your quality of life can make any potential financial struggles more manageable.

Klein, P.A.’s Cherry Hill divorce lawyers represent clients in a variety of divorce cases, including gray divorce. By working with an experienced Cherry Hill divorce lawyer, you ensure that you are able to create realistic expectations for the future. Becoming informed and addressing any potential issues early in the divorce process can minimize problems later down the line. Do not let gray divorce be a major burden on your retirement. item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Lower Marriage Rates Can be Fixed by Divorce Reform
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Marriage is becoming a less common option for many individuals. The percentage of married men aged 20-39 has halved in the last 35 years. Roughly, this corresponds to about two generations. There are several possible reasons for this sharp decline since the 1970s, but the most likely one finds divorce rates to be responsible - specifically, the perception that many men have of divorce. In the 1970s, the divorce rate skyrocketed. With this, the “risks” many men associate with divorce have become a much larger factor in deciding whether to marry.  Men’s Perception of Divorce Affects the Desire to Marry Many men have a negative perception of marriage due to divorce. In fact, many may find that the possibility of happiness in marriage is not worth the possibility of experiencing divorce. Another factor is that women have historically been favored in custody cases over men, which leads to the perception that a marriage that ends in divorce could also lead to a painful separation from a man’s children. Studies have also found that women are more likely to file for divorce than men, which may account for the lower rate of married men compared to women. In light of such numbers, there have been large movements to change family laws to reflect and account for these biases, with bills concerning such laws pending in 25 states. Shared Custody May Help Shared parenting is the main reform that has been proposed for custody laws. A greater increase in shared parenting/shared custody could greatly improve the damaged perception of divorce. Shared parenting is often in the best interest of the children as well as parents, and could lead to more men deciding to be married due to the lower “risk” involved. A higher marriage rate would lead to many benefits for society as a whole.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Changing Your Name After a Divorce
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
A name is an integral part of a person’s identity. A name is used for establishing credit, arranging public services, paying bills, and more. Naturally, changing a name involves the legal system. Yet, changing your name after a divorce in New Jersey is not that complicated when done right.

How to Change Back to Your Maiden Name

Many states make changing one’s name because of marriage or divorce difficult. New Jersey is not such a state, provided the person getting divorced follows the law. When a person marries in New Jersey, the ability to change their name is as simple as presenting their marriage certificate to the Motor Vehicle Commission, Social Security office, creditors, and other interested parties. Changing your name after a divorce can be nearly as simple. New Jersey allows either party to a divorce to change their name at the time of the divorce. The judge will simply rule the change to be so and it will be so. Then the person making the name change need only present the official court papers to interested parties. This is the easy way. Sometimes people do not make a request to the court for a name change at the time of the divorce proceedings. Regardless of the reason, if this should happen a person will have to follow a more complicated route. New Jersey follows a name change process that first requires filing a petition in the local Superior Court. This will consist of swearing out an affidavit that your reason for requesting the name change is not to avoid prosecution of a crime or for the commission of a crime, such as fraud. Next, you will need to place a notice in a local newspaper stating that you intend to change your name. Interested parties will need to be notified as well such as creditors, landlord, bank, etc., and you will need to bring proof of these notifications to court. Next, you will have to state your case for the request to change your name to a judge. Assuming he or she rules in your favor, copies of the court documents will then have to be forwarded by you to the Registrar of Vital Statistics and the state Department of Treasury. Finally, once the name change is complete, your former name may not be used under any circumstance and any civil suits you face will remain valid.

When Children Are Involved

If children are involved in the divorce, some parents may ask the courts to also change their names to reflect the custodial parent name. This is seldom approved, with most courts preferring to leave the paternal name with the children. However, there may be instances where making a name change is in the best interests of the children; the courts consider each case on its merits.

Although changing your name after a divorce may seem a simple thing, experience shows that things do not always go as planned. To be safe, the best thing to do is let the Cherry Hill divorce lawyers at the law offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. handle the name change for you. Arrange a free consultation online or call now 856-988-5470.

item.title: Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers: Connecting with Stepchildren
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
No relationship is perfect and every relationship requires effort. This is no better seen than when two people with children from previous marriages decide to wed. One of the most difficult relationships any person can form is one with stepchildren. This is so for many reasons, not the least of which involves deep-seated emotions. Still, it is possible for stepparents to connect with stepchildren. Following are some ways to build strong, lasting bonds.

Time, Patience, and Perseverance Needed With Stepchildren

One of the most difficult things for new stepparents to understand is that children need time. Remember that in most cases, the children have had far less time to develop a relationship with the new parent as their biological parent had in forming the relationship. All relationships take time. Furthermore, their biological parent chose to have a relationship with you; the child did not. Children, like adults, need to feel respected. When a relationship is forced on them, they naturally pull away. So, the first and perhaps the most important thing for a new stepparent to remember is to give the child time. The amount of time needed for a child to bond with a new stepparent depends largely on the age of the child. Research indicates that children not yet in school will bond rather quickly, within a couple of years. Older children, however, will require as many years as their age. So, do not expect a teen to bond anytime soon. Be patient. Aside from needing time to become familiar with their new stepparent, children will have difficulty finding the line between allowing you into their life and feeling as though they are not betraying their other biological parent by doing so. They may feel that if they care about you, they are somehow failing to care for the parent no longer living in the home. Such feelings can also cause them to lash out in seemingly irrational ways. It is worth repeating. Be patient. Finally, as the adult in the relationship, the stepparent will need to exhibit perseverance. Know that the child’s parent chose you because of qualities he or she admired. The child will likely also respond to these qualities, but it will take time for natural biases to be overcome. You will need to persevere in seeking the relationship, but must take care to not force it. No one can be forced into liking anyone else, regardless of their age and role. Being too pushy will drive a wedge between you and only make things more difficult.

Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers at Richard C. Klein, P.A. Help Blended Families

Research shows that when parents fight, it negatively impacts the non-cognitive functions of children. We try to help families part ways as amicably as possible to reduce the harm to children during divorce. This helps children better adjust to social changes later, such as when one parent remarries and they have a stepparent. The Cherry Hill divorce lawyers at Richard C. Klein, P.A. are more than court representatives, we are family advocates. If you live in Cherry Hill, Moorestown, Mt. Laurel, Marlton or anywhere else in New Jersey, let us help you through this difficult time. Contact us online or call now 856-988-5470 for a free consultation.

item.title: Make Summer Co-Parenting a Breeze
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Summer is here, which means baseball games, ice cream, or an unforgettable trip to the Jersey Shore. Summer is a time of endless fun and freedom for your kids, but can sometimes mean more frustration and stress for couples going through a separation or divorce. The Law Offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. focus on family law in New Jersey and can help make sure you have the relaxing summer you deserve. Parents will face a myriad of new challenges such as agreeing on how to divide parenting time, deciding on schools-out custody arrangements, divvying up the bill for summer camps, and learning how to successfully co-parent to eliminate the tension and stress that goes in hand with a divorce. Children of divorcees will also be navigating a challenging time and learning how to cope with their parents’ separation and their newly divided schedules. They will undergo a series of new emotions: anxiety from the divorce and fear of not spending enough time with the non-custodial parent. They may experience sadness because they miss the other parent’s constant presence, or feel resentment. If a new potential step-parent is introduced into the equation, the child will need to learn to adapt, which can be scary. Balancing time with your kids over summer break can be challenging with the boundless activities that arise during the season. Cherry Hill child custody lawyers at the Law Offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. can transition you through this daunting time. Here are several tips to make summer co-parenting a breeze: Be flexible:  Summer is a busy time for both parent and child, especially in a single parent household. If last minute arrangements need to be made, or the co-parent wants to take your child out of the country to travel, try to work out an agreement with them.  Have rational conversations about the fears and concerns present. Successful co-parenting involves heavy compromising and sometimes deviating from the agreed upon custody schedule. Put the children’s best interest first: Seek their input for summer activities and whom they want to spend their time with. Last minute sleepovers or events might come up and could cut into your scheduled custody and quality time with them. Everyone will have a little less time with each other after a divorce. Do not let your child resent you for controlling all their time without consulting them. Discuss summer expenses: the expenses could be shared equally by both parties, or it could be decided that a child support and alimony agreement covers it. Be realistic; if one parent is footing most of the day-to-day childcare expenses, then it is fair for the co-parent to incur more of the summer costs. Notify the child’s parent about vacations: This eliminates last minute scheduling and allows both parents and their children to have the stress-free time off they deserve.

If you are looking for an advocate to give you the best solution for child custody agreements in New Jersey, look no further than the Law Offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. item.title: Custody Options in New Jersey
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
As many divorces are not amicable, there can be jealousy, sadness, and often anger. In addition to hard feelings, there are a multitude of complicated legal issues for parents and the courts to manage. One of those issues, and often a very painful one for parents and children, is custody.

What is Joint ‘Legal’ Custody?

Joint legal custody is when both parents make decisions regarding their child’s life in areas such as healthcare, education, and religion. Parents with joint custody have access to a child’s medical and school records and have the ability to choose if the child attends church or religious education through Confraternity of Christian Doctrine (CCD).  Legal custody exempts child support as the courts prefer both parents be involved in the lives and welfare of their children, and will often elect to award joint custody.

What is Physical Custody?

Physical custody, also know as residential custody in some New Jersey courts, determines which parent the child will live with. One parent may have full physical custody while the other one has visitation rights. Structured visitation occurs when there is a set schedule for when one parent sees their child. Joint physical custody includes a schedule of when the child will be with each parent. In certain situations, the child may stay with one parent for longer periods of time. Custody can impact how child support is calculated. In cases where one parent has full custody of a child, the other parent is usually ordered to pay child support to the custodial parent. Where parents have joint custody, the parent with the higher salary can be ordered to pay child support to the other parent. Courts often order child support even if the parents have joint custody, while considering the type of physical custody agreement parents have, as well. There are several factors in determining child support formulas in different states, including the number of children, daycare and health insurance costs, and income. While parents may have come to a decision regarding physical custody, there are many factors to sort out during a trying and emotional time. Divorce is a process that changes the family dynamic and has life-changing impacts.

Building relationships to better meet the needs of our clients is our top priority. We communicate regularly with clients to give and receive updates, address concerns, and answer questions about the legal process. item.title: How to Change Child Custody in New Jersey
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
After divorce and child custody have been awarded, the needs of the family and children may change. One parent may need to take different job, perhaps in another location, or parents may remarry. In such situations, there may be a need to alter custody arrangements.

Two Ways to Change Child Custody in New Jersey

If both parents are agreeable to the change, they can put the new terms in writing and petition the court for a motion to alter the existing child custody arrangement. Both parents must stipulate in writing that they want this agreement to replace the existing custody order. Once the judge signs the new order, it is final and the new child custody arrangement takes effect. When drafting the new arrangement, the parents may choose to write and file it themselves with the court or they may prefer to use their divorce lawyer. Most have an attorney handle the paperwork and filing to ensure the process is handled correctly. The second method of changing child custody in New Jersey requires modification proceedings where the two parties appear before a judge and present their case for the change. There could be two hearings to attend. In the first hearing, the judge will assign a mediator to help the former couple work out the best new child custody arrangement. If the mediator can get the parents to agree on new terms, the matter is forwarded to the judge who then approves and signs it. However, if the two are not able to come to terms with the mediator, there will be another hearing in front of the judge. During the second hearing, the judge is going to want strong evidence presented for the change. There must be strong and compelling evidence presented that proves this change is in the best interest of the children. The burden of proof is on the parent or parents. If the situation involves complex issues which cannot be sorted in a brief session, the judge may set a new date for a plenary hearing. A plenary hearing is like any other case whereas with the initial hearing, the only people present are the parents, children, attorneys, and witnesses, if necessary. This is a more extensive hearing during which allegations may be substantiated and proofs submitted.

item.title: New Jersey Child Support Statute
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Individuals that pay child support need to stay up-to-date with support laws and statutes. One of the best ways to stay informed is to contact a Cherry Hill divorce lawyer. We will keep you informed of any changes in New Jersey child support laws. Recently, the New Jersey courts passed a statute regarding the cutoff age for child support. The Termination of Obligation to pay Child Support, N.J.S.A, went into effect and declares the age of 19 to be the legal cutoff age for support unless parents have worked out another agreement where the cutoff age would be 23. Many parents wonder about child support age limits as it is important to note that age limits vary by state. Parents can also work out special terms that extend or limit child support based on several factors. A child with special needs, enrolling in college can have their support extended or terminated. States base the support termination age on the age of majority, when a child is no longer considered a minor and is now an adult. People believe the age of adulthood is 18, but that is not the age of majority for every state. In New Jersey, the age is 19. When a New Jersey child reaches the age of majority, the support order is immediately null and void. Typically, termination takes effect on the child’s birthday. Custodial parents or guardians must draft an amended agreement before the child’s 19 birthday to ensure continued support.

Special Needs

The statute offers protections for children with disabilities or special needs. Under Section E, parties can draft a financial agreement that takes effect after the support order ends. The difference between the support order and the agreement lies within the courts. New Jersey child support courts will not be responsible for the enforcement of the agreement or payment collection as everything is left up to the parties. Children with special needs have additional care costs figured into their support order. Once that ceases, both parties may require help determining the amount each side needs to contribute. Now that the child is an adult, they may be eligible for an individual insurance plan. This can alter the conditions of a financial agreement and a Cherry Hill divorce lawyer will help work out the details.

College

If a child enrolls in college before turning 19, the child support order remains in effect. Typically, the custodial parent submits a college expense support application to the courts and the courts take the parent’s income history and any financial aid or scholarships into account. Once officials have reviewed all relevant information, they decide in the best interest of the child. Courts can decide to increase or decrease support based on several factors, such as the child’s living arrangement, as courts may reduce the order if the child lives on campus.

A Cherry Hill divorce lawyer at the Law Offices of Richard C. Klein can help clients draft a child support agreement. If you need help understanding the statute and drafting an order, call us today at 856-988-5470 or contact us online.

item.title: Keeping a Family Together After Divorce
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
The dissolution of a marriage is emotionally, mentally, and financially exhausting. However, the divorcing parties still need to interact with each other to finalize the divorce and raise their children. Therefore, they need to learn how to communicate effectively and move forward.

Effective Communication

Couples going through a divorce still have a responsibility to be open and honest with each other. A breakdown in communication is not healthy for either party. Couples must still respect each other’s personhood and carefully select their words. Language and tone are very important. Avoid using offensive language and refrain from speaking in an aggressive tone. This may seem difficult at first, but it is vital to keeping communication open. Allow yourself time to think and cool down before speaking to your ex-partner.

Be Supportive

A divorce is life-changing and it will prompt each partner to explore a different lifestyle. You must respect your ex-partner’s path and lend support when you can. If they have expressed desire to go back to school or learn a new trade, do not discourage them. Instead, talk to your ex-partner to find out what prompted this change and wish them the best. Ask them if they need extra help with the children during this time as this shows that you are being supportive and you understand their needs. People often develop a new sense of independence after divorce. This is perfectly normal and vital to their healing process. Allow your partner to grow by supporting their endeavors.

Help Them Find a New Place

This step may be particularly difficult but it is necessary if you have kids. Typically, somebody moves out of the home during the divorce process. According to law, the other party must find a home that can accommodate children. You can help by attending real estate showings with them, by giving them some input, or help them create a budget to go house shopping. Talk to the children and ask their opinion and find out what features they want in their new home. If you do not want to become too involved, then do a final walk-through of the home or apartment at buying. Familiarize yourself with the area and the layout of the home as this will make travel arrangements easier for the children.

Stay Updated

After divorce, it may be tough to keep each other informed of any changes in your lives. However, it is necessary for each party to inform the other of any changes to their schedule, living arrangements, or job. Major changes can affect child support or custody orders. The best way to stay updated is to check in with each other every few months. Conversations do not have to be long, but they should be clear and informative.

If all else fails, then a mediator is the best way for ex-partners to communicate after a divorce. A Cherry Hill divorce lawyer from the Law Offices of Richard C. item.title: Unemployment Leads to Divorce
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
A recent study from Harvard showed that money is still a major contributor to divorce. The study found that in heterosexual couples where the man is unemployed, the divorce rate increases exponentially. Married men that lose their jobs are 30 percent more likely to divorce within a year of termination.

The Rise of Feminism and Divorce

The data analyzed was not recent. In fact, researchers looked as far back as the 1970s to learn more about divorce trends. The 1970s and 80s were the beginning of the great American divorce surge. This was during the time of the second wave of feminism. Women were finding their independence and working outside of the home. Women are the primary initiators of divorce. At least two-thirds of divorce proceedings are initiated by females. In the 1970s, unemployed men were three percent more likely to get divorced compared to employed men. Unemployment has a negative impact on the overall health of the marriage. Couples are more likely to fight over money and it can lower the unemployed partner’s self-esteem. Surprisingly, studies show that unemployment in women does not negatively impact relationships as much as male unemployment. Researchers attribute this to the circumstances surrounding a man’s unemployment. They assume that most males are involuntarily unemployed, meaning they are laid off, fired, or forced to resign. Female unemployment is attributed to other factors such as childbirth, and it is considered less burdensome on the marriage.

Unemployment Triggers Contempt

Couples dealing with unemployment may find that arguments increase and negative behaviors surrounding money will arise. The unemployed party may feel the need to control the flow of money and dictate the financial decisions in the home. Unemployed divorcees may also have a difficult time bouncing back after the dissolution of the marriage. Research has revealed that potential suitors find credit card debt unattractive. Unemployment is not a death wish for the marriage. It can be worked out through both couples’ and financial counseling. The problem is that unemployment can lead to other marital issues or make current problems worse. Couples struggling financially are more likely to communicate less with each other and take out their frustrations through arguments. This leads to the breakdown of the relationship.

Cherry Hill Divorce Lawyers at the Law Offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. Can Help You Navigate Your Divorce

The study confirms that economic uncertainty contributes to major issues in society. In an economy where people are unemployed or underemployed, divorce is rampant. A Cherry Hill Divorce lawyer from the law offices of Richard C. Klein, P.A. will be able to assist clients dealing with the dissolution of their marriage due to financial troubles. item.title: August is Child Support Awareness Month
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
August 2017 marks the 22nd anniversary of National Child Support Awareness Month, a month of recognition across all 50 states. National Child Support Awareness Month was created by former President Bill Clinton in 1995 to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Child Support Enforcement Program. National Child Support Awareness Month was created to recognize the necessity of child support programs at all levels of government, and the efforts of the professionals who operate them. It is meant to acknowledge those programs which ensure that children receive necessary financial support to lead a healthy and happy quality of life. The theme of the 2017 National Child Support Awareness Month is “Give them something great to imitate.”

Child Support Awareness in New Jersey

In New Jersey, the Office of Child Support in the Department of Human Services oversees child support and enforcement, focusing on several different facets of the issue. While the Office initially was focused mainly on tracking down and enforcing support payments, their efforts have expanded. Rather than simply enforcing, the Office also provides support to parents who must pay child support. The Office makes efforts toward helping parents understand and fulfill their responsibility. The Office focuses on being supportive and understanding, and helps parents play a critical and involved role in their children’s lives, financially and emotionally.

Child Support Issues - Looking Ahead

Another important purpose of Child Support Awareness Month is to focus on the work that still needs to be done. Statistics show that there is still a need for improvement in child support systems.
  • As many as 13.7 million parents have custody of 22 million children under age 21 while the other parent lives elsewhere.
  • Sixty-one percent of the $35.1 billion in child support due in 2009 was reported as received.
  • Child support made up 62.6 percent of the average income for impoverished custodial parents who received full support. Sixty-one percent of unmarried mothers reported that their income was below $30,000 in 2012.
  • In 1960, 8 percent of mothers with children in their custody were single mothers. Today, roughly 31 percent of mothers are unmarried.
While improvements have been made in many areas, it is important to focus on reform and improvement ahead.

item.title: The Surprising Reasons Why a Child Has Difficulty Visiting Their Other Parent
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Divorces can be difficult for children to process. No matter the age of the child, they have grown accustomed to a two-parent household and they expect things to remain that way. The separation of their parents may be hard on children, both mentally and emotionally. These children are not used to shuffling back and forth between households or splitting time between parents. As a parent, you will do everything you can to make the transition easier, but sometimes things are beyond your control. A child may have a hard time letting go and outright refuse to see their other parent. This puts the you in a precarious position as the custodial parent. You do not want to disrupt your child’s time with their other parent but you do want to ensure that there is nothing wrong. Typically, visitation is dependent on a court order. Couples may agree to joint or partial custody agreements. When a court order is in place, it is usually mandatory for a child to visit the parent at that appointed time. Of course, if parental parties have an amicable relationship, they may be flexible with the custody agreement. However, some structure is important to avoid confusing the child.

The Adjustment Phase

If the child knows when they are scheduled to visit the other parent and there is still pushback, you may want to delve deeper into the problem. Children notice body language cues much easier than most people realize. Their anxiety regarding leaving with the other parent may be a projection of what you are feeling. If your child notices that you are sad or anxious every time they leave, they may become uncomfortable. Children do not like seeing their parents upset and the child may feel like they are upsetting you every time they leave with the other parent. In response to this perceived slight, they will begin to pull away from the other parent and get upset when you expect them to leave. Another reason for your child’s behavior can also be a response to the custody agreement. The child could be having a very difficult time splitting time between two parents. They are used to spending time with both parents in the same house. This new experience is tough for them and they may act out in the hopes that you two will try to spend time with each other. One of the biggest reasons for a child’s discomfort also has to do with adapting to change. They may not feel comfortable going to a new home with the other parent. Moving is difficult for children and they feel like they are moving every time they go over to the other parent’s home. They must pack a bag, use a bathroom they are not familiar with, travel to another area, and these things may all trigger separation anxiety. The best way to deal with the child’s discomfort is to seek the help of a therapist and a Cherry Hill divorce lawyer. The therapist will help the child work through their issues and the lawyer will help you draft a custody agreement that works for all three of you.

item.title: Back-to-School Tips for Co-Parents
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Back-to-school preparations are hectic even in the best of times. As the fall approaches, it is important for co-parents to begin to prepare for the complex issue of schooling in a shared-custody environment. As a child goes back to school, it is important for them to feel support and caring from both co-parents. In order to achieve this, communication and coordination is key. There are a few tips to keep in mind when attempting to give your child a smooth and straightforward back-to-school transition.

Maintain Open Communication and Coordination with Co-Parent

It is important to stay on the same page when in a shared-custody situation with a co-parent. Make sure that you are open and forthcoming with the child’s co-parent regarding any upcoming school events or scheduling. Allocate responsibilities to each co-parent appropriately. Even relatively simple issues, such as making sure that your child has all the proper materials for school and extracurricular activities, can be made difficult without open and honest communication. Some co-parents find that a regular family meeting can help smooth over communication problems and keep everyone on the same page effectively.

Keep Focus on the Child

It is not always easy to remain civil with a co-parent. However, it is important to avoid getting caught up in unnecessary competition. Keep focus on your child’s well-being, rather than the child’s perception of you or their co-parent. It is important to try to remain civil, so that both co-parents can attend important school events together. Whether it is simply supporting your child by coming to a sporting event, or obtaining important information from a parent-teacher conference, it will be easier on each co-parent and more supportive for the child if both parents are present.

item.title: In-laws May Contribute to Divorce, Study Finds
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
The notion that in-laws cause problems in marriages is long-standing. To learn whether this was truly so, a team from Cambridge University’s Center for Family Research decided to study the matter. What they found was both telling and surprising. In conducting the study, the team questioned hundreds of participants who were estranged from their families. What they found was that although there is truth to the view that in-laws can be troublesome to relationships, the reasons were not as expected.

Families Involvement with New Partner

In times past, marriages were arranged for financial reasons or strongly kept within religious and social circles. If someone sought marriage outside of acceptable standards, they were often ostracized or disinherited. Pressure to comply with choosing someone acceptable to the faith or the family was strong, so problems with in-laws tended to be minimal. Today, people take a soul-mate view and marry for love, regardless of social, familial, or religious ties. This often places a strain on relationships with in-laws who may see the partnership as threatening their family. The Cambridge researchers determined that part of the reason for this could be the later age that many people marry. The later age provides the couple with the emotional stability to weather the potential of ostracism. They also found that the relationships most strained in modern marriage are between sons and their parents. Moreover, children were more likely than parents to break ties when a discord occurred related to their choice of partner. This is a complete turn from previous generations.

Wives’ Role

The most startling part of the study was that it appears the reason men remain estranged from parents in difficult marital situations is because of his relationship with his wife. Because women tend to be more active in choosing the social calendar for the family, when a husband’s parents make it known they do not approve of the wife, she cuts them from social engagements. Often wanting to please his wife, researchers noted that the man will often go along with these arrangements, if only to keep the peace. Such situations cut both ways, but if the problems are between the man and his in-laws, it is not as intense. Another factor the study revealed was that women stated estrangement from parents based on emotional abuse and mental health problems. For men, the reason to cut ties from parents often centered on divorce, marriage, and in-laws. This appears at odds with the initial findings but shows that in-laws do play some role in dividing marriages. Marriage is a difficult partnership regardless of pressures from in-laws, but when in-laws oppose the choice of partner, a special strain develops. Most relationships simply cannot bear the strain from meddling in-laws. Regardless of the situation, when a marriage reaches the breaking point, it is usually best to find a lawyer who can help the couple make the best of a bad situation.

item.title: Dating After a Divorce
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Some individuals never date again after they divorce while others jump right back into the dating pool. Most people fall somewhere between these two extremes, taking time to recover emotionally and financially from their divorces before they start trying to meet potential new partners. When a divorced individual decides it is time to date again, they can face a few dilemmas such as where to meet somebody to date and how to connect with a prospective new partner again. Most people who return to the dating world after a divorce are in a different stage of their life than they were when they met their spouses. An individual who only dated as a 20-something can face significant challenges identifying what they want in a partner and how to reach ideal partners as a divorced 50-something.

Give Yourself Time to Be Ready to Date Again

There is no specific period of time after a divorce where it becomes acceptable for an individual to date again. An individual should start dating again when they feel ready, which could be a few months or up to a year or more after their divorce is finalized. Many individuals reach this point after they have adjusted to living as a single person. During this time, it is important for an individual to reflect on what they did to contribute to their marriage’s breakdown and take steps to learn from those behaviors. Many individuals find it helpful to work through this process with a psychological counselor. Approaching new relationships with destructive habits or bitterness over one’s divorce will not yield positive results.

Take Time to Meet a Variety of People

An individual in the dating scene should never discount a source of potential partners. A relationship can start at work, at the gym, at one’s child’s school, or even just in the individual’s neighborhood. Divorced individuals looking to date should make an effort to put themselves into a variety of settings, ideally settings that make them happy. This could mean joining a recreational sports league or trying a new hobby like painting or music. Confining oneself to a specific setting or “type” can cause them to miss out on great opportunities to meet new partners.

Keep Your Dating Life Separate from Your Children at First

Parents are advised to keep their children separate from their new relationships until the relationships are committed. Meeting a parent’s new partner too soon after a divorce can be stressful for a child, and subjecting a child to a regular stream of short-term partners can be confusing and upsetting. Some parents wait six months to a year to introduce their children to their new partners. Others wait until they plan to move in together or once they become engaged. The right timeline for introducing children to one’s new partner varies from person to person, and often depends largely on the child’s relationship with the parent and their maturity level.

item.title: Domestic Violence an Issue Across All Social Classes
item.dc:creator: michele
item.content:encoded:
Domestic violence is a serious concern in the U.S. Although some people mistakenly believe domestic violence only affects women in impoverished and minority communities, nothing could be further from the truth. Domestic violence impacts men and women of every race and socio-economic standing. In fact, among the more affluent, violent home situations are often worsened because of the higher economic situation. Further, the issue becomes more complicated for victims in affluent neighborhoods for a number of reasons.

Facts and Misconceptions About Domestic Violence and Income

One of the largest misconceptions about domestic violence is that it only affects persons living in poverty. Part of the reason for this misconception is that research is limited according to the data collected. Because many victims who live in affluent neighborhoods fear the social ramifications to making the situation known, silence becomes a barrier to receiving help. It also becomes a barrier to researchers learning the facts. Often, a victim of an abusive relationship is virtually trapped by the affluent partner, who is most frequently male. The abuser holds the purse strings and the victim has little in the way of resources. The victim knows that if they phone the police for help, several things will happen. First, the neighbors will know and often, the victim will be shunned in the community. If the victim decides to seek a divorce, she or he will have to find a way, with little to no income, to survive.

Is Domestic Violence More Common in Affluent Neighborhoods?

Along with other underlying factors, the stress associated with maintaining a higher standard of living can trigger an abusive relationship. Yet, it is not that affluence creates stress, but economic uncertainty associated with a volatile market that triggers dangerous stressors. Again however, little is yet known because those living in affluent neighborhoods tend to remain silent. Finally, another element that plays into the issue is the nature of the properties in which the affluent live. Homes are larger and there is often more space between properties. In such a situation, an abuser can be as loud as he wants and the victims can scream or cry, but neighbors do not hear. Thus, phone calls are not made to authorities in such surroundings as they are in physically closer communities. This physical element may be another key factor explaining why there is less data related to in-home violence and abuse in affluent communities.

Domestic violence does not discriminate, but victims are not without help. The Cherry Hill divorce lawyers at Richard C. Klein, P.A. understand that abuse can strike anyone at any time. We also understand that when a person lives in an affluent neighborhood, discretion is a must. If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic violence and needs help escaping a bad relationship, we can help. Our caring and compassionate attorneys will meet with you in confidence and help plan an exit strategy that will both ensure your safety and your dignity. Whether you live in Cherry Hill, Camden County, Burlington County, or Atlantic County, New Jersey, contact us online or call now 856-988-5470.

item.title: Will I Have to Sell My Home?
item.dc:creator: kristen
item.content:encoded:
When couples divorce, many important questions arise. Where the parties will live after the divorce is finalized is one of the main issues. But then the question of who is entitled to keep the home inevitably arises. How the property is divided can depend on the law in the state and also the behavior of the parties. New Jersey divorce law provides for equitable distribution of marital assets. This means the court will order the couple’s assets and debts be divided fairly, though this does not always mean the assets will divided equally. When deciding which spouse will stay in the home, the courts will consider whether there are children involved and which parent will retain primary custody of the children. The court may also look at whether the home was bought by one of the parties prior to the marriage or if it was purchased together. Other issues to take into account are the value of the home and which party is more likely to be able to afford to stay in the home going forward. In some instances, one spouse will buy-out the other. Alternatively, one party will live in the home for a specified amount of time and then sell the property and divide the profits. If the parties cannot decide, a judge could decide that the house be placed on the market immediately. On the other hand, if the parties agree on which person should remain with the home, the other party could be awarded other possessions of value or alimony to offset any inequities. Other issues that typically arise are removing one party’s name from the mortgage if they will not be contributing to monthly payments. If a judge decides your case, he or she will most times award the home to the party who will be the primary caretaker of minor children. The purpose is usually to provide stability for the children and to keep them in the same schools while parents are divorcing. Some parents have chosen to keep the children in the home and instead of the children going from home to home, the parents will rotate in and out of the home on a weekly basis. This set up requires much coordination on the parents’ part, but it can be arranged and will likely only be successful if there was a stable home for the children prior to the divorce. This is an unusual solution, but when parties work together, many different solutions can be possible and it is not always necessary to sell a martial home immediately as the divorce is occurring.

item.title: How Divorce Affects Your Government Retirement Savings Plan
item.dc:creator: kristen
item.content:encoded:
As a Federal employee, a divorce or separation can affect your Thrift Savings Plan (TSP). Your TSP is a retirement fund and investment plan similar to a 401k. Your agency matches your contributions to the TSP which is known as the defined contribution format. TSP operates in conjunction with the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) and the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS). The FERS and CSRS are retirement systems with multiple components. The Federal Employees Retirement System has three types of funds available to workers. The CSRS has an additional annuity plan available to its workers. The TSP is just one of the funds represented in a government retirement plan.

How Assets Are Divided

The division of assets after a divorce depends largely on the state’s laws. Even though you are a Federal employee with a Federal fund, your assets are still divided based on individual state law. There are no Federal guidelines pertaining to the division of the TSP during a divorce. When dividing assets, states usually follow one of two statues: equitable distribution or community property. Only a handful of states believe in the community property law. In those states, all assets acquired during the marriage are split equally between both parties, meaning your former spouse will be entitled to half of your TSP. Your former spouse is only entitled to the money you contributed during the marriage. You and your attorney will have to calculate the marital contributions and that sum will be split with your former partner. New Jersey is an equitable distribution state, meaning a judge will decide how assets should be divided and distributed. The judge will listen to both parties and base his or her decision on a variety of factors, including the length of the marriage and the earning capacity of each spouse. Assets do not have to be divided equally, the former spouse is entitled to a portion deemed “fair and equal” by the judge. If you and your partner are still amicable, you can work out a financial agreement that is favorable for the both of you. This agreement will be drafted by an attorney and it is called a marital settlement agreement. The attorney submits the agreement, also known as a divorce settlement, to the courts. The courts will create an order that will validate the agreement.

Gaining Access to the TSP

The Federal government will normally freeze your TSP during the divorce proceedings. In order to access the account, you will need a Retirement Benefits Court Order (RBCO) or a Qualified Domestic Relations order (QDRO). A divorce settlement or decree qualifies as a RBCO. The RBCO should state the percentage or amount of funds your former spouse will receive. The government looks closely at a QDRO and an RBCO. Specific language must be used or it will not be recognized. Taxes will not be taken out of your TSP until funds are withdrawn. The spouse can agree to a lump-sum or monthly payments.

item.title: Domestic Violence During Pregnancy
item.dc:creator: kristen
item.content:encoded:
News stories of pregnant women injured and killed by their partners are sadly not uncommon. In a relationship where domestic violence is present, a partner’s pregnancy can escalate episodes of physical violence. When a pregnant woman faces violence from a partner, she is not the only party at risk of harm. The developing fetus can also be impacted by violence, which can cause it to suffer birth defects or for the mother to suffer a miscarriage. In less extreme cases, the mother’s stress can negatively impact the fetus’ brain and immune system development.

Pregnancy Changes a Couple’s Dynamics, Which May Spark Abusive Behavior

In any relationship, pregnancy means a dramatic lifestyle change, which can change a couple’s dynamics. Disagreements about lifestyle and finances can be intensified because of the changes the couple has to make to accommodate their new baby. According to Denise McCain, Director of the Prince George’s County Family Justice Center in Maryland, pregnancy can intensify acts of abuse in relationships where a pattern of abuse already exists. This can be because the abusive partner feels threatened by the unborn child or because they feel additional stress about their upcoming shift in responsibilities and pressure to provide for a new family. In some cases, abuse stems from jealousy on the part of the abusive partner.

Domestic Violence Victims Must Put their Safety First

Whether a victim is pregnant or not, they should know how to safely leave an abusive relationship. The first step to improving safety is knowing how to recognize domestic abuse, which is not always physical. Emotional, psychological, and sexual abuse can be used instead of or alongside physical abuse to control a victim. When a pregnancy is the result of a victim being prohibited from using birth control or the abuser tampering with the victim’s birth control, the pregnant woman is a victim of sexual abuse. Individuals in abusive relationships should stay in regular contact with their families and their doctors. A victim’s doctor can advise them about how to remain safe and healthy amid the abuse and what to do in the event they are injured or experience illness symptoms. Victims should also be in contact with their local domestic violence hotlines to develop escape plans and have a way to contact local law enforcement if an abusive partner becomes violent. Once out of an unhealthy marriage, the victim should seek a restraining order against their former partner to increase their level of protection. A restraining order can prohibit an abuser from contacting their victim and impose other restrictions, like requiring them to get rid of any firearms they own and prohibiting them from purchasing additional guns. In any case, the most dangerous thing a victim can do for themselves and their child is to stay with an abuser. Many victims stay in harmful relationships because they fear retaliation for leaving. However, every day a victim remains, they risk being injured or killed.
